title: Great company culture
pros: positive work life balance, fair pay, good learning opportunities
cons: Lack of monetary incentives to stay in role, moving roles every couple years is only way to significantly increase pay

title: Good Company
pros: They have the desire to improve from where they are, meet customer demands, huge market share of the industry, opportunities internally to move around, awesome products, deep rooted sense of purpose serving both the military and commercial sectors.
cons: Promotions without changing roles are difficult, work life balance is gone, (the term 24/7 is dropped too often for a company that isnt staffed for it), too many leaders in every thing that may cause a delivery delay, celebration for the fire fighters and little focus on how to get out of it, only on how to do more of it. Healthcare is expensive.
advice_to_management: Learn to trust your teams and stop asking for daily or to the minute updates. There are levels in the org for a reason and it shouldn’t be to have all of them in every issue or to have to communicate every issue up to the highest levels. The continued brute force approach will result in burnout across the board. The goals are achievable, enable your people figure it out and stay out even if they stumble. They’ll ask for help when they need to.

title: Great place to work
pros:
Treated with respect. Ideas are listened to and implemented when possible. 
Most people are helpful. The work is important. Good benefits
cons: Pay should be higher for custom built parts.

title: Good benefits
pros: Good benefits but they got rid of the pension plan before I got there. So not quite as good as it used to be
cons: It’s one of those very large shops where your just a number. So many people work there that you could work there for a decade and not know everyone’s name. Some people aren’t very nice and many ppl will tell on you for doing something wrong.

title: Knowledge does not Equal Pay
pros: Good worklife and overall values.
cons: Groups can vary in culture. Some great, some neutral, and some awful. Overall, the business has treated the military side more poorly than the commercial side. Money, events, etc. Title doesn't mean anything; you can be a lower engineer and teaching higher paid "leads or senior"  engineers that just got hired and have no transferable skills. Executive management is something else. Company surveys constantly rate their communication skills poor and they skip over it. Or better yet they do address it and say they're not part of it, when executive is literally in their title.
advice_to_management: Ask about the management, more specifically, the expectations to be promoted. Some groups do it quickly, some will low ball you for as long as possible.

title: Overall Good Company
pros:
Laid Back.

cons:
Waiting on other can get tiring.
Periods of not many projects.

title: GE review
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Pay can is good for the area but can lag behind compared to averages.

title: Potential to be a Great Work Place
pros:
- Some teams are great to work with
- Good health, dental, and vision insurance
- Interesting Work
- Flexibility of when working (be available during core hours, otherwise flexible as long as you're getting your work done)
cons:
- Air of arrogance in some teams
- Little opportunity to give feedback to direct managers and leadership
- People are viewed more as 'Cog in the Wheel' rather than individuals
- Opportunities for greater than minor raises are difficult. Average (Meeting Expectations) rating includes going above expectations within the description, this is held strongly in reviews.
- Too much focus on hours spent towards projects. Salaried workers are required to work 95% of time towards project work (aka applied hours). Company community groups, trainings, general meetings, vacation, appointments, and others are all considered non-project work (aka non-applied hours).
- Not understanding or supportive of mental health and disabilities, little knowledge in HR about the actual utilization of support programs
advice_to_management:
- Get rid of the applied vs non-applied hours tracking, or at least make the ratio more balanced
- Train managers and leadership on mental health and disabilities, and the available support programs for employees
- Change review process to include individuals who have more knowledge and insight of the employees every day work and interactions, not just managers who are not interacted with more than once every few weeks and don't see employee work first-hand.

I'm currently in a new role after moving from a previous nightmare here, thinking that was a one-off situation, but this is turning out to be the same. Definitely fitting that they still worship Edison and strive to be "engineers" (read: corporate scum) just like him. Also constant messages to donate our personal money to the scummy political PAC campaign lobbyists so they can continue avoiding taxes and having dinner with Trump.

Inside

good dental insurance

advice_to_management:
The mechanics there today have an 
Education (A&P)
Do more then the old timers
Get payed less for the time
Pay 10000% more for insurance 
Never been on strike 
And still the company just takes away benefits like
1 Pention 2 double time early call-in 3 Sputnik 4 affordable healthcare 5 regularly buy lunch for the shop 6 when you retire you can take home your tool box I know I am missing a dozen other things your employees are not the enemy

title: Best Work-Life-Balance and Work Flexibility in F500
pros:
- Unlimited PTO that you can and are encouraged to use
- We promote family-first and mean it from Executive to Engineer
- Easy six figure pay package
- Lots of experiences to gain for a lucrative exit
- Highly diverse leadership chart (men, women, LGBTQ, cultures)
cons:
- There is more work than employees to do it
- Corporate buzzwords still exist like every other F500
- Career advancement is possible, but the higher up the management ladder you climb, the more challenging it becomes - as with every other F500; at some point, making lateral moves is the best you can do while negotiating pay increases
- Compensation could be more competitive with tech companies, because we have billions to make that a reality, but we often, perhaps rightfully so, heavily invest it back into the business
advice_to_management: I am the management. But we are not all the same.

title: Great Culture

advice_to_management: None.

title: RACISM at its highest quality
pros: None, I was treated very poorly.
cons: RACISM at its highest quality at GE Aerospace Semiconducting Lab in Niskayuna NY. Everyone working in the lab including the manager is white. I was the only colored worker in there for only 1 week before I was let go. I have a total of 6 year’s semiconducting experience and everyone working in the lab that I spoke with confirmed with me that they had zero experience prior to starting there. Their reason for letting me go after one week of work was that I didn’t have enough experience. Wouldn’t the specific experience needed come with 1 year of training that they promised? I wasn’t given a fair chance to prove my work ethic and abilities. How would you feel if this happened to you, knowing that you were the only colored person working there and was let go with this excuse after only 1 week of working knowing that you’re capable of doing a job that you know is very easy for you? On top of that, the government pays them with tax payers dollars to work for 8 full hours and out of the 8 full hours, they only work for about 4-6 hours, but they make sure to document in eTim that they worked for a total of 8 hours.
advice_to_management: They could’ve given me a fair chance to prove my abilities.

title: Welcoming environment and team, laid back culture, and solid work experience.
pros: GE's UX team in one of their DT orgs is super nice, friendly, and laid back. My role was UX - Interaction design and I got the chance to work on other projects outside of my role with front end coding. Pay is pretty solid for the Cincinnati area. Their work/life balance is very good and you can work remote/in person whenever you want.
cons: Onboarding was messy with their transition away from general electric as the main company. Most of the team is remote so it's hard to make connections with other people working in your field, but other interns often go in person. GE is VERY slow and sometimes doesn't have enough work for interns to do. I had to ask my manager for more projects a few times, but it's not a huge problem. As for UX there isn't too much hiring going on for more UX designers, but DTLP is still a good option to get diverse experience (for junior year interns).
advice_to_management: Provide more areas for interns to work in.

title: Great workspace
pros: Great workspace and loving community between workers.
cons: Hours can be a little drastic at times

title: Great company to work for
pros: Cutting edge technology, ability to try many things
cons: Many out dated procurement systems

title: Great workers, awful management
pros:
Interesting work
Wealth of IP to learn from
cons: No time to sit and learn the depth of your assignments. Get it done ASAP

title: GE
pros: All the work you want, performers are abused and are rewarded the same as non-performers. Their merit, job performance, system process is awful.
cons: Little to no recognition to technical leaders. Company highers unskilled, unexperienced, managers.  They do not terminate, or even improve, non-performers, they just move them around creating waste. Annual reviews are primarily subjective and majority of managers have little depth in knowledge or actually ever completed a project.
advice_to_management: Evaluate employee roles and value they add to the yield of the company. Many employees only contribute 20% of their worth.

title: Controls
pros:
Unlimited vacation, could be a con for not knowing your limit
Hybrid 3-2 work from home
cons:
Slow paced 
Lots of documentation 
Average yearly raise ~3%

title: The best!
pros:
Flexible
High paying 
Growth opportunities
cons:
Long approval process

title: Great Company for Engineering
pros:
Permissive Time Off (I've never had a PTO request rejected)
Flexible Schedule
Access to basically any training opportunity
Professional development is highly promoted
Not too much red tape when it comes to continuous improvement initiatives
Safety-focused
cons:
Yearly bonus is tied to business metrics that my site doesn't contribute to
Lots of growing pains trying to implement Lean company-wide

title: Nice area to work in
pros: Wonderful people working there. Enjoyed my time there.
cons: There really was no downside

title: GEA Sourcing
pros: Pay OK for the position

advice_to_management: Get a heart.  What goes down, comes down. You'll have your turn on the chopping block.

title: Great
pros: great company love them a lot

title: AMD has interesting work but suffers from "musical chairs"
pros:
Good Benefits
Plenty of work
Plenty of standardized work and specifications to learn new hardware if no prior experience
Work life balance dependent on individual programs and teams, typically you can work a hybrid schedule
cons: Company program priorities change often and thus cause hardware ownership to change often. You will have to stop work, catalog it, then move to something else without finishing the project

title: Great benefits and people
pros: Great place to work. Cares about their people
cons: Lot of red tape to get anything done and some level of beaurocracy.
advice_to_management: Trust the engineers to do the job they’re paid to do

title: GE is Good
pros: People, Bonus, Culture, Product, Coworkers
cons: Structure, Leadership, Benefits, Change, Facilities

title: Great People
pros: GE is a great place to work, depending on the team you are on. The level of talent and intellect is impressive and 99% of the people I worked with were incredibly considerate and kind. Don't get me wrong - it's not an EASY place to work, the challenges are difficult ones to solve but at least you'll likely be on a great team.
cons: The lower salary range compared to competitors is why I decided to leave. A bit behind on the latest technologies as a whole.

title: A matter of perspective
pros: Great pay, lots of opportunity for the strong willed
cons:
Working with Union members.

Every time you hear “thank a Union Member” look at the current state of Detroit.

Pretty much sums it up.

title: It’s pretty decent
pros: Positive work environment, flexible work options, good people, respect for work life balance, focus on employee safety
cons: Salaries and benefits are not competitive with industry peers. Pay scale is complicated and highly subjective.
advice_to_management: Pay your people better

title: Company review
pros: Great team dynamic. Fast pace and paid for overtime. Not expected to put in the extra time but managers show appreciation. Recognized when you put in the work to hit target dates.
cons: Benefits not the greatest. Could improve. In the past had better medical coverage. Pension no longer offered.

title: Big company with big ideas and flexibility
pros: Freedom to work and contribute in meaningful ways; Deep pockets for project work
cons: Manufacturing culture is challenging at times, just like any other manufacturing site

title: Love working here
pros: Pay, experience, learning, benefits, growth
cons: None in my current role at GE Aerospace

title: Great experience
pros:
- Networking
- Leadership Experience
cons: - Frequent moving around for different rotations

title: Great workplace
pros: Great teams and learning environment
cons: Work life balance can be hard sometimes

title: Say goodbye to work-life balance and say hello to never ending stress
pros: High salary compared to other companies and flexible time off policy.
cons:
Terrible work-life balance. They will work you to the bone. Many long hours are expected of you

Highly stressful job.

Severe lack of adequate training. Most training is on the job training or buried in outdated specs that are not always clear.

Leadership needs a lot of improvement.

Many terrible people to work with. Argumentative, pushy, vindictive, power hungry, hateful, stressful to deal with, have a lack of fundamental understanding of quality and its role, and are generally very unhelpful to go to with questions. Not everyone is this way, but there are definitely some that I wonder how on earth they got into the positions they are in.

Yearly bonus structure is based on you if you meet or exceed expectations on yearly goals. Whether you meet or exceed those goals is highly subjective and dependent on your manager. Because of this, it is nearly impossible to get all exceeds expectation marks, which means you will almost never get your full potential bonus for the year.

Company 9 times out of 10 will prioritize shipment goals over quality goals. If a quality problem comes up all management cares about is how quickly can the issue be resolved and shipments sent out.
advice_to_management:
Get rid of the people that have nothing better to do than bring down the morale of everyone else. Realize that people have lives outside the company and are not robots. 

Get more organized and properly train people before throwing them to the wolves. 

Hire more people before ramping up production and attempting to hit outlandish yearly goals.

Create a less subjective yearly goals system.

title: painful
pros: looks good on my resume
cons: literally did not care at all about interns or their experiences
advice_to_management: dont lose interns files

title: Great place to work

title: Manufacturing Intern
pros:

High focus on quality and GD&T

Great pipeline into development programs like Edison
Great overtime
cons:
Takes a long time to make any change, and you need approval from 1000 different people
High up leadership doesn't focus on the little guy, so can be frustrating watching the union workers do something wrong and they have to do it that way since the top refuses to adjust on their side

title: Good company, no
pros:
Teams are generally supportive and open to new ideas. Cross-functional collaboration is encouraged, which allows for a range of perspectives in problem-solving.

There are ample opportunities for learning and growing in your role, especially for those eager to expand their technical skill set. The company supports personal development through training and access to a variety of tools.
cons:
The pace can sometimes feel intense, with tight deadlines and competing priorities. This can lead to a challenging work-life balance at times.

While there are opportunities for growth, the process for moving up or changing roles within the company could be more transparent.

pros: GE Aerospace is flexible with allowing permissive time off. Management is supportive in general and I enjoy my highly technical work.

title: Good Place to work

cons: not a place to just do your 8 hours and expect to be promoted. You must go above and beyond. Work 30% of your time and participate in projects the other 70% of your time
advice_to_management: Probably review your work force capacity and realize that 40% of the employees do not work.

title: Power Systems Engineer
pros: Great work and very challenging.
cons: Its a big company so progress can be a bit slow.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Enjoy working on cool projects
cons: I have no cons so far.

title: Decent
pros: The benefits are very good
cons: Management was generally very lacking
advice_to_management: Listen to your employees

title: Lack of structure
pros: Permissive time allows for a flex vacation schedule
cons: Forced to work long hours, constant firefighting prevents any actual progress from being made

title: Mixed environment
pros:
* There are some very good people that work here, but there are also people you have to wonder how they passed an interview. 
* Get to work in a large enterprise environment.
cons:
If ya have a miserable boss, your life becomes a living hell. If you have a good boss, then it's an enjoyable experience. Each time a employee leave due to a RIF or a Retirement, those left standing suffer the brunt of additional tasks. Even if the the employee's plate is already full.
Never have the ability to take technical training beyond the introductory stuff in LinkedIn Learning.  If you need anything in depth training wise, you're out of luck.
Lots of antiquated systems that you have to fight to keep running.
advice_to_management:
*Clamp down on the success theatre middle managers, and stop the belief  that you have to give a person more work in order for them to advance their career.  There are many roles that are simply overworked, and it's kinda disheartening to know to advance their careers, they have to take on even more work.
* Offer real technical training opportunities.
* Benefits are crazy expensive, and cover less than other employers
* No career advancement if you didn't come into GE direct from college into one of the leadership programs.  So if you joined GE after being in the Industry, the management ignores your presence.

title: Overall good experience so far...

title: My Favorite Employer
pros: fantastic place to work - great culture
cons: large company so easy to feel lost in the shuffle at times

title: Recent Intern Review
pros: GE Aerospace has a great culture with regard to interns. Interns are treated well and given opportunities to learn about many functions through various events, tours, individual meetings, and through day to day networking. Intern work is meaningful, fulfilling, can be tailored towards intern interests, and can be deeply technical depending on the role and duration of the internship. The company by nature has a very broad set of engineering disciplines which work towards similar goals and integrate well.
cons: I don't think I want to live in Ohio.

title: Fulfilling a life calling
pros: work on problems that matter to our world and get to do so in a way that is of the highest level of integrity
cons: not specific to GE, this industry goes through seismic shocks from time to time and is not for the faint of heart

title: Archaic systems, little room for growth
pros:
Salary is very competitive for Industry
PTO has never been denied
Hybrid arrangements are extremely common
Great for Early Career or Late Career professionals
cons:
Systems are extremely old, every initiative to upgrade them gets canceled after 1 year
In order to gain salary raises you have to move roles, this leads to high turnover among all levels of leadership
Overloaded desks are common
advice_to_management:
Encourage and reward those who stay in-role or in their teams.
Business really needs to take a look at the system infrastructure and figure out what they're going to do with it

title: Average
pros: Leadership makes attempts to address issues, and overall the environment has improved in the last 5 years.
cons: GE makes no secret of their attempt to limit benefits and pay to below average, but expects employees to be the best in the world.

title: Manufacturing engineer
pros: Great flexibility and overall benefits
cons: Work load continues to increase without salary reviews

title: Great
pros: Great culture and benefits package
cons: Could be better at work life balances. No work sometimes

title: Salary
pros: Great company, highly competent employees.
cons: Stressful and poor work-life balance. Bureaucratic and not always clear processes.

title: Great Start to Career
pros: 1-on-1 mentorship, relocation assistance, etc
cons: Sometimes it can be underwhelming

title: Bad vibes
pros: Working in the space department, directly contributed to NASA SLS.
cons: No communication between the various networks of cubicles often leads to lack of work for long stretched of time, confusion, mismatched part vs drawings, and finger-pointing on the production floor. Production workers have no control over those problems that they are blamed for. This is brought up countless times at meetings and in general conversation. The solution is to quietly persecute anyone that dares to question the status quo.
advice_to_management: I suggest you don't fire people for using FMLA. The DOL would like to have a word with you.

title: transformation in a strong business
pros: intelligent team, a lot of good people, the business is really solid and appears to have a lot of external tailwinds, the products are meaningful (really incredible technical achievements)
cons: working in transformation at at company that is not doing poorly is tough.. many people believe we don't need to do anything differently, there are a lot of centralized jobs (HQ roles) for an industrial company, often times decisions are made away from the work being done
advice_to_management: let's decide if we're serious about transforming the business to unlock all that value that exists.. even though results are strong, there is still so much waste in our operations

title: Alright Company

cons: With the rate of change, it can be hard to keep up with the latest and sometimes the change happens, but is not well communicated to the org.

title: Progressive Workplace
pros:
Very interested in making their engineers happy with good work/life balance. The permissive leave is legit. I originally was skeptical but have found it so useful.
Career and professional growth is pushed and highly encouraged. Everyone wants to see those around them succeed. Competition isn't really something I notice like I did when I was enlisted in the Navy.
cons: The pay isn't the most transparent. And even the sub-section managers are in the dark quite often. They've made some strides but it's obvious at a high level, someone wants it to remain somewhat ambiguous.

title: Recommended - but room for improvement
pros:
Great team providing an important service to today's world.
Good pay and opportunities to advance.
cons: Management is often detached from day to day operations.. and have a track record of making decisions that hurt us in the long run.
advice_to_management: promote technical talent to avoid losing your best employees.

title: Great opportunity

cons: Very Large company and in beginning of being on their own

title: Good
pros: Flexible and lots of pto
cons: Teaming environment can be hostile

title: Good work life balance, low career growth
pros:
- Permissive time off has never been rejected, 10 base holidays with several floaters
- Interesting engine development work environment
- Good company culture, coworkers are friendly and helpful
cons:
- Little visibility in career progression
- They pay you as little as they can get away with
- Tons of red tape and archaic systems that make a lot of your day to day work more difficult

title: Pay
pros: They offer good pay for their employees
cons: Have fun working 12 hour shifts and be penalized if you need a day off

title: Good
pros: Friendly people who are eager to help you learn
cons: proper onboarding/integration into team was at times not great

title: Workplace
pros: Great Pay and Time off, Site Leader and People leader are awesome people.
cons: Extremely skewed Ethnically and I experienced a lot of bias in relating with older colleagues on teams who are all unconsciously biased and management tends to listen more to them for opinions and assessments and not actual objective processes. This leaves too much room for subjective assessments and evaluations. No laid out training for new hires apart from OJT, you have no Genfam or class session to introduce you to tools and engines you work with and this can lead to complacency as many lean heavily on memorizing processes and not necessarily following manuals or having new hires guided through use of these manuals.
advice_to_management: Implement a proper and objective assessment and evaluation process. Also put in place a formal training regime where staff are taken to class and given the theoretical aspect of the tools and engines they work on before throwing them to the floor.

title: Run
pros: The pay and benefits are the only thing making it worth working here, until I find something else.
cons: The culture here is the most toxic environment I have ever been in. Flat level management, has given many people the idea that they are in charge, when they are in fact, not. There’s hardly any accountability and certain individuals feel they can do as they please. The way new hires are trained and treated is unsatisfactory to any other place in the industry or any non-industry place I have worked. If you do not fit in well with the team you are placed on, you are going to have a rough 90 day probation period. Many of the young, early 20-something’s (who can is a majority of the workforce) act like this is a fraternity and with no checks and balances in place, they get away with sitting back and playing on their phone most of the day and hardly do any of the work that needs to be accomplished. Do yourself a favor and just go find a job working anywhere else, save yourself from stress and headaches.
advice_to_management: Flat level seems great on the outside because it gives the false impression that you have empowerment as an employee, but really it makes people feel empowered to treat others as though they manage them, instead of being equals. Teaming needs a rework. Find a way to match new hires with teams that they will fit in with. The toxic culture needs to be addressed, too.

title: Great place to work
pros: Inclusive culture and great work life balance
cons: Large company so burocracy can be frustrating
advice_to_management: Keep all the good WLB and benefits for employee retention

title: Good Company
pros: People are friendly, and eager to help sometimes.
cons: Too corporately structured for me.

title: Good experience
pros: GE Aerospace offers an innovative, collaborative environment where employees can work on cutting-edge technologies, contribute to strategic decisions, develop advanced technical skills, and be part of sustainable advancements in the aerospace industry.
cons: No cons for the company

title: GE Aeropsace
pros:
Time Off - no constraints for vacation- as long as performing job function Vacation/Personal/Sick-Leave -Permissive Leave.
Pay is competitive. Bonuses and Retirement Savings is same as industry- up to 4% matching at 50% of what employee contributes (8% required to max out GE contributions)
Flexibility on workday with hybrid and remote opportunities depending on position
cons: High Cost Medical Benefits- 2x industry
advice_to_management: Improve healthcare costs and eliminate ties healthcare costs to employees who have higher salaries. One price for all employees. Update internal outdate systems to prevent constraints for the business.

title: GREAT COMPANY
pros: Flexible. Great Work Culture. Great Benefits. Room for Growth.
cons: Fast-paced work environment and can be stressful.

title: good standing
pros: very good stating with company
cons: very long hours with paper work
advice_to_management: very stressful and time consuming

title: GE Aerospace Pros and Cons
pros: You have Unlimited Paid Time Off
cons:
Work Culture not so great
Pay below industry

title: Excellent benefits
pros: Caring employer and great benefits pkg
cons: Na Na Na Na Na
advice_to_management: Na

title: Good place to work
pros: Collaborate environment to work in.
cons: Regular structural changes leading to poor management.

title: You might consider other options if you have them
pros: I used to be excited about the job now I’m not so it’s hard for me to find any positives.
cons: GE recently implemented mandatory billing by each salary employee to bill 1800 hours to programs. What this means is if you have overhead for training or meetings that aren’t built to a program or even paid time off you have to make up the time or you could just take no time off and have about three weeks of training and meeting time available to you. While others in the industry are going with the 9/80 schedule, GE has just gone with a 10/90. What they need to do is eliminate some of the middle management that we’re paying for that don’t bill to programs and it would free people up and give them a better work life balance, which GE likes to claim we have..
advice_to_management: Get rid of some of the management we have too much.

title: Good Long Career with Plenty of Opportunities
pros: Endless opportunities to grow, learn and take roles all over the company
cons: Work life balance, you need to stand firm on this
advice_to_management: Demonstrate work life balance & help support it more

title: Love it
pros: Great people, great culture. Good benefits. Tons of internal mobility.
cons: I can't think of any.

title: Great Experience
pros: A lot of very knowledgeable engineers willing to help you learn more about the field and industry.
cons: Getting the technology set-up was very slow and took multiple weeks.

title: New But Happy
pros:
I get to work with smart folks
I get to touch significant impacts on the aerospace industry
cons: Large companies have large bureaucracies
advice_to_management: Consider lean as a tool and not a rigid template

title: Great
pros: Great team, collaborative, wonderful environment, good pay
cons: none none none none none

title: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work here
cons: Very very busy and high demand

title: Ge aerospace
pros: Good benefits, unlimited pto, flexible
cons: Micromanagement, no work life balance,

title: Good
pros: Great company to work with
cons: No comment as for now

title: Fake positive Glassdoor reviews are lipstick on a pig
pros: Nice colleagues. Some interest from candidates because an established company.
cons: Company is adding engineering talent and some of the more honest, spot-on reviews are being buried on Glassdoor. Many that I worked with seemed to dislike their job. Contractors are treated like excrement throughout the organization, for some reason they're good enough to string along as contractors but not good enough to become full time. You'll be lead to believe that you'll eventually become a GE employee but the odds of that happening are unlikely. They run their engineers into the ground.
advice_to_management: Go elsewhere

title: Great Potential, Process Dominates
pros: Great people, great product, super successful engineering of aerospace technology.
cons: Change is real, process is dominating the culture. Hard to accomplish the job due to overwhelming process.
advice_to_management: understand the people as much as the tasks.

title: Review
pros: Good Culture, interesting work, purposeful
cons: Long Hours, direction can be unclear with the teams

title: Internship Review
pros: Positive culture with a supporting team
cons: Interns at locations other than HQ weren't as involved in internship activities

title: Tricky site
pros: Aerospace has a vast support org for all things someone would need from HR/Benefits to function job support
cons: The site specifically in Rutland really struggles with consistency and is constantly changing

title: Incredible potential
pros: Vast knowledge base, especially for an aerospace geek, with tons of learning potential. As a programmer, my direct supervisor was incredibly knowledgeable and easy to work for. My work load was pretty much up to me to decide how much I wanted and when I wanted to do it as long as it got done.
cons: Floor employees fight progress every step of the way, largely due to aggression between management and a lack of opportunity/rewards. Development is rushed and production demands take precedence over quality and process improvements. Much of the mid to entry level management staff are on rotations and their metrics are too myopic so they worry about day to day production instead of big picture projects. Most of the mid to entry level workers are focused on their next advancement and don't take pride in their work.
advice_to_management: Take the time to really understand the scope of development projects and the higher level metrics. Sacrificing a couple of weeks of production targets to meet next year's quality and cost quotas are completely worth it. Incentivize the floor and support team with awards and events to build a stronger culture. Spend more time empowering entry level employees with robust training programs and hearing their voice. Focus all staff on a singular overarching strategy and work on having better buy in.

title: Okay place to work
pros:
Benefits 
No forced overtime
Good hours
cons: Pay once you've been here a while doesn't keep up with the rest of the GE industry
advice_to_management: Pay us like the rest of GE Aerospace

title: Good Place
pros: Good culture, good people, solid WLB
cons: occasional lack of WLB on certain projects

title: Typical Aerospace Company
pros: GE is a typical aerospace company - decent pay, great WLB, and supportive coworkers.
cons: Reluctant to change, stuck in their old ways.
advice_to_management: Let go of the old ways.

title: Great company to work for
pros:
-Mentorship opportunities
-Postgraduate opportunities
-Wide range of networking and role opportunities
cons: -Some teams are fully virtual

title: Amazing Experience!
pros: This company has one of the best working environments, and the culture/people is absolutely amazing!
cons: Since it is a manufacturing company the technology is not as fast paced as Microsoft or Amazon, but it also teaches you how to learn from a business perspective

title: Ux researcher role
pros: Great company to work for
cons: Project based roles can be worrisome

title: Great Company!
pros: Good company. Great benefits and PTO
cons: Not any. The company treats people well.

title: Great place to work
pros: Supportive atmosphere and great teams
cons: Supply chain challenges, industry wide

title: Great
pros: Great place to work, flexible, many leadership opportunities available.
cons: The emphasis on being a leader can be too much if you don’t desire that.

title: Engine CS SW
pros: Hours Flexibility, training opportunities, LEAN mentality
cons: Salaries would need to be more competitive. Changes are not easily to apply.
advice_to_management: Dont forget to focus also in the professional development of your people.

title: World-class technology and talent
pros: A great place to be if you're fortunate enough to be here. The opportunity to grow in your career through challenging and rewarding work is nearly limitless. One thing will always be true about this company, the people here are special.
cons: With GE splitting its core business units, leaving GE Aerospace as a standalone organization, the opportunities for career movement in SG&A functions has declined. A microscope on cost has created an environment with little internal movement or new jobs available.

title: Flexibility
pros: Flexibility, work life balance, culture
cons: Limited career opportunities, not the latest in technology
